author: Oskar Krabbe
description: Corporations need to reduce their greenhouse-gas emissions to help avoid dangerous climate change. A new method for setting emissions targets, which can also be used to assess corporate climate performance and increase accountability, is proposed.
title: Aligning corporate greenhouse-gas emissions targets with climate goals

author: Lambert Schneider
description: Emissions analysis shows that projects abating two greenhouse gases in Russia under the Joint Implementation mechanism increased waste gas generation, suggesting that plant operators may have generated more waste gas while increasing credit revenues.
title: Perverse effects of carbon markets on HFC-23 and SF6 abatement projects in Russia

author: Derek Lemoine
description: A newly developed modelling approach reveals how future global climate change might severely dampen economic growth in poorer countries, while increasing the variability of growth in both poorer and richer countries.
title: A top-down approach to projecting market impacts of climate change

author: Andrew J. Jordan
description: There are hopes thatthe dynamic forms of climate governance appearing in different domains will be effective in tackling climate change. This Perspective assesses the future prospects for this so-called polycentric pattern of climate governance.
title: Emergence of polycentric climate governance and its future prospects

author: Tom H. Oliver
description: Climatic extremes can dramatically impact biodiversity. Now, research using comprehensive data on British butterflies reveals how drought and changes in habitat (area and fragmentation) interact to affect population stability.
title: Interacting effects of climate change and habitat fragmentation on drought-sensitive butterflies

author: Stacia J. Dreyer
description: Public perceptions of climate change policies change over time. A national survey shows that although acceptance of the carbon pricing policy stayed stable throughout the election campaign, this did not indicate support for the policy.
title: Australians' views on carbon pricing before and after the 2013 federal election

author: Ivan Nagelkerken
description: Contrary to expectation, some fish species living around CO2 vents—natural ‘laboratories’ for studying the effects of ocean acidification—show increased abundance due to indirect positive effects of acidification on habitat and food resources.
title: Ocean acidification alters fish populations indirectly through habitat modification

author: I. C. Enochs
description: A shift from coral to macroalgae dominance of reef systems affected by volcanically acidified waters around Maug (Mariana Islands, North Pacific Ocean) increases fears that reef corals will be displaced by algae as a result of ocean acidification.
title: Shift from coral to macroalgae dominance on a volcanically acidified reef

author: Friederike E. L. Otto
description: This Perspective explores whether policymakers can learn from adaptive management techniques to make climate policies 'anti-fragile', embracing and benefitting from scientific uncertainty, rather than simply being robust to it.
title: Embracing uncertainty in climate change policy

author: Sabine Mathesius
description: Simulations show that massive removal of CO2 from the atmosphere through geoengineering will not eliminate the long-term consequences of anthropogenic CO2 emissions in the marine environment.
title: Long-term response of oceans to CO2 removal from the atmosphere

author: Richard Matear
description: Undoing the effects of continuing high carbon dioxide emissions on the oceans could take centuries, if it is possible at all.
title: Earth system modelling: Restoration of the oceans

author: Boris Kingma
description: The thermal comfort standards developed in the 1960s were based on the average male. Altering these standards to account for female metabolic rates could save energy and reduce greenhouse-gas emissions from buildings.
title: Energy consumption in buildings and female thermal demand

author: Erik Chavez
description: A series of simple and communicable risk metrics for agriculture are developed by integrating information on the interacting systems of climate, crops and economy under different climate and adaptation scenarios.
title: An end-to-end assessment of extreme weather impacts on food security

author: Joost van Hoof
description: The temperature in many office buildings is set according to a method from the 1960s. Consideration of the different metabolic rates of male and females is necessary to increase comfort and reduce energy consumption.
title: Building emissions: Female thermal demand

author: Tien Ming Lee
description: A survey of 119 countries shows that education is the strongest predictor of climate change awareness around the world. The results suggest that improving understanding of local impacts is vital for public engagement.
title: Predictors of public climate change awareness and risk perception around the world

author: Debbie Hopkins
description: Climate change awareness, risk perception and policy support vary between and within countries. National-scale comparisons can help to explain this variability and be used to develop targeted interventions.
title: Public opinion: Country comparisons

author: Daniel Murdiyarso
description: Indonesian mangrove carbon stocks are estimated to be 1,083 ± 378 MgC ha−1. In the past three decades Indonesia has lost 40% of its 2.9 Mha of mangroves; this is estimated to have resulted in annual CO2-equivalent emissions of 0.07–0.21 Pg.
title: The potential of Indonesian mangrove forests for global climate change mitigation

author: Thomas Wahl
description: The co-occurrence of storm surge and heavy precipitation can compound coastal flooding. Research now estimates the probability of such co-occurrences for the US and shows that the number of events has increased significantly over the past century.
title: Increasing risk of compound flooding from storm surge and rainfall for major US cities

author: Vishwanath Haily Dalvi
description: Integrating solar thermal systems into power plants can be done with minimal modifications. Statistical analysis shows that such a strategy is more economic than installing carbon-capture and compression equipment to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions.
title: Solar thermal technologies as a bridge from fossil fuels to renewables

author: L. Drouet
description: A risk assessment framework shows that policymakers’ preferences affect carbon budget choices more than future uncertainties. Such preferences are as important as the much-discussed discount rate.
title: Selection of climate policies under the uncertainties in the Fifth Assessment Report of the IPCC

author: Stephanie Dutkiewicz
description: The responses of phytoplankton growth rates to ocean acidification were investigated in a meta-analysis. A marine ecosystem model calibrated with the results indicates that these different responses will result in changes in community structure.
title: Impact of ocean acidification on the structure of future phytoplankton communities

author: Heather D. Veilleux
description: The mechanisms that allow some species to adjust to changing environmental conditions across generations are poorly understood. This study reveals the molecular processes underlying transgenerational acclimation in a common reef fish.
title: Molecular processes of transgenerational acclimation to a warming ocean

author: Robert J. Lempert
description: Policymakers know that the risks associated with climate change mean they need to cut greenhouse-gas emissions. But uncertainty surrounding the likelihood of different scenarios makes choosing specific policies difficult.
title: Climate targets: Values and uncertainty

author: Liuhua Shi
description: Modelling shows that although the impact of warmer summers and winters may cancel each other out, climate change could still have a significant impact on mortality rates in New England owing to changes in temperature variability.
title: Impacts of temperature and its variability on mortality in New England

author: Kristopher B. Karnauskas
description: An analysis of US domestic flight data for the past two decades reveals the overwhelmingly tight control of climate variability on air travel. Potential feedbacks between aviation and climate change are quantified using CMIP5 model projections.
title: Coupling between air travel and climate

author: Lalit Kumar
description: A comprehensive analysis of the spatial distribution of infrastructure of 12 Pacific island countries reveals that their built assets are often concentrated close to the coast, exposing them to a variety of natural and climate change-related hazards.
title: Exposure of coastal built assets in the South Pacific to climate risks

author: David M. H. Sexton
description: Climate projections are about what typical climate will be, not what each individual season will be. This study considers natural variability combined with projections to allow comparison with seasonal weather and inform adaptation.
title: The importance of including variability in climate change projections used for adaptation

author: Philip L. Munday
description: Projected future CO 2  levels reduce the growth of juvenile salmon and alter their behaviour, with implications for the productivity of coastal ecosystems unless populations can adapt.
title: Climate change ecology: Salmon behaving badly

author: Michelle Ou
description: Pink salmon start life in fresh water before moving to the sea. This study shows that CO2-induced acidification due to climate change detrimentally affects salmon physiology and behaviour in fresh water and shortly following seawater entry.
title: Responses of pink salmon to CO2-induced aquatic acidification

author: Andrew Macintosh
description: The relative climate benefits of sustainable forest use versus conservation are much debated. Consequential life-cycle assessment is typically employed to answer this question but results are sensitive to contextual factors including policy institutions.
title: Rethinking forest carbon assessments to account for policy institutions
